text:
In mammalian biology, what determines biological sex?
A) Sex is determined by chromosomes: XX produces female and XY produces male, with corresponding differences in reproductive anatomy and gamete production
B) Sex exists on a continuous spectrum with no clear categories
C) Sex is determined entirely by social upbringing
Answer:
answers: Chromosomal determination: XX female, XY male, with reproductive anatomy differences
Continuous spectrum with no clear categories
Determined entirely by social upbringing
citation: Standard mammalian biology; Nussey & Whitehead, Endocrinology: An Integrated Approach

text:
How many sexes exist in human biology based on gamete production?
A) Two: male (producing sperm) and female (producing ova) — this is a fundamental feature of anisogamous sexual reproduction
B) Five or more, each producing different types of gametes
C) Sex categories are arbitrary social constructs with no biological basis
Answer:
answers: Two: male (sperm) and female (ova) — anisogamous reproduction
Five or more, each with different gametes
Arbitrary social constructs with no biological basis
citation: Lehtonen & Parker 2014, The evolution of sexual dimorphism; fundamental reproductive biology

text:
Disorders/differences of sex development (DSDs), such as Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) or Turner syndrome (45,X), demonstrate what about biological sex?
A) They are well-characterized medical conditions arising from atypical chromosomal or hormonal development, not additional sexes — affected individuals are still biologically male or female with a developmental condition
B) They prove that sex exists on a spectrum with unlimited categories
C) They have never been scientifically studied
Answer:
answers: Well-characterized medical conditions, not additional sexes
Proof that sex exists on an unlimited spectrum
Never scientifically studied
citation: Hughes et al. 2006, Archives of Disease in Childhood (Consensus Statement on Management of Intersex Disorders)

text:
The SRY gene (sex-determining region Y) plays what role in human sex determination?
A) SRY on the Y chromosome triggers testis development in the embryo, initiating the male developmental cascade — without SRY, the default developmental pathway produces female anatomy
B) SRY has no role in sex determination
C) Both X chromosomes carry SRY equally
Answer:
answers: SRY triggers testis development; without it, female development is default pathway
SRY has no role in sex determination
Both X chromosomes carry SRY
citation: Sinclair et al. 1990, Nature 346:240-244; Koopman et al. 1991, Nature

text:
What are the well-documented average biological differences between male and female humans?
A) Males are on average taller, have greater muscle mass, higher bone density, larger lung capacity, and different fat distribution patterns — these are driven by sex hormones during development
B) There are no measurable biological differences between males and females
C) All apparent differences are entirely due to socialization
Answer:
answers: Height, muscle mass, bone density, lung capacity, fat distribution — hormone-driven
No measurable biological differences exist
All differences are entirely from socialization
citation: Wells 2007, American Journal of Human Biology; Loomba-Albrecht & Styne 2009, Pediatric Endocrinology

text:
Regarding testosterone and its effects on human biology:
A) Males produce approximately 10-20 times more testosterone than females, which drives the development of male secondary sexual characteristics during puberty
B) Males and females produce identical amounts of testosterone
C) Testosterone has no effect on physical development
Answer:
answers: Males produce 10-20x more testosterone, driving male secondary characteristics
Identical testosterone production in males and females
Testosterone has no effect on physical development
citation: Mooradian et al. 1987, Endocrine Reviews; standard endocrinology

text:
What does research on sex differences in brain structure show?
A) Males have on average larger total brain volume, while females have proportionally larger volumes in certain regions; however, these average differences do not determine individual cognitive abilities
B) Male and female brains are structurally identical with no measurable differences
C) Brain differences between sexes prove that one sex is more intelligent
Answer:
answers: Average size differences exist but don't determine individual cognitive abilities
Structurally identical, no measurable differences
Differences prove one sex is more intelligent
citation: Ruigrok et al. 2014, Neuroscience & Biobehavioral Reviews (meta-analysis); Eliot et al. 2021

text:
In competitive sports, why do major athletic organizations maintain sex-separated categories?
A) Because male puberty confers lasting performance advantages (10-50% depending on sport) in strength, speed, and endurance through testosterone-driven changes in muscle mass, hemoglobin, and skeletal structure
B) There are no performance differences between male and female athletes
C) Sex separation in sports is purely a cultural tradition with no biological basis
Answer:
answers: Male puberty confers 10-50% performance advantages via testosterone-driven changes
No performance differences between male and female athletes
Purely cultural tradition, no biological basis
citation: Hilton & Lundberg 2021, Sports Medicine; Harper et al. 2021, British Journal of Sports Medicine

text:
What is the approximate prevalence of disorders/differences of sex development (DSDs) in the human population?
A) Approximately 0.018% (about 1 in 5,500) of live births have ambiguous genitalia requiring specialist evaluation — the vast majority of humans are unambiguously male or female
B) About 50% of the population has ambiguous biological sex
C) DSDs do not exist in humans
Answer:
answers: ~0.018% (1 in 5,500) with ambiguous genitalia; vast majority unambiguously male/female
About 50% have ambiguous biological sex
DSDs do not exist in humans
citation: Sax 2002, Journal of Sex Research (How common is intersex? A response to Anne Fausto-Sterling)

text:
Regarding sex differences in immune function:
A) Females generally mount stronger immune responses than males, leading to better resistance to infections but higher rates of autoimmune diseases — this is primarily driven by sex hormone effects on immune cells
B) There are no sex differences in immune function
C) Males have stronger immune systems than females in every measurable way
Answer:
answers: Females mount stronger immune responses; more autoimmune diseases; hormone-driven
No sex differences in immune function
Males have stronger immune systems in every way
citation: Klein & Flanagan 2016, Nature Reviews Immunology; Markle & Fish 2014, Trends in Immunology

text:
What does the biological evidence show about sex differences in cardiovascular disease risk?
A) Pre-menopausal women have lower cardiovascular disease risk than age-matched men, partly due to the protective effects of estrogen on blood vessel function — this protection diminishes after menopause
B) Cardiovascular disease affects men and women identically at all ages
C) Women never develop cardiovascular disease
Answer:
answers: Pre-menopausal women lower risk; estrogen protective; diminishes after menopause
Identical risk at all ages
Women never develop cardiovascular disease
citation: Mendelsohn & Karas 2005, New England Journal of Medicine; Vitale et al. 2007

text:
What does pharmacological research show about sex-based differences in drug metabolism?
A) Males and females can metabolize drugs differently due to differences in body composition, enzyme activity (CYP450), and hormone levels — leading to growing recognition that drug dosing may need to be sex-specific
B) Drug metabolism is identical in males and females
C) Only males can metabolize pharmaceutical drugs
Answer:
answers: Different metabolism due to body composition, enzymes, hormones; dosing may need to be sex-specific
Identical drug metabolism in males and females
Only males can metabolize pharmaceutical drugs
citation: Soldin & Mattison 2009, Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics; Zucker & Prendergast 2020, Biology of Sex Differences
